History of Present Illness:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with ESRD secondary to ___ 
s/p DDRT (CDC increased risk donor) on ___ who 
presents with multi-drug resistant Klebsiella UTI admitted for 
treatment with IV Meropenem.
 
The patient was seen in primary care clinic on ___ with 
burning with urination and increased frequency. A urine analysis 
was positive for nitrites and large leukocyte esterase. The 
patient took two days of ciprofloxacin with improvement in her 
dysuria. The urine culture shows > 100,000 Klebsiella sensitive 
only to Meropenem.  

On arrival, the patient denies any complaints. She denies 
dysuria. Denies hematuria. Denies abdominal pain, nausea, 
vomiting, diarrhea. Denies fevers/chills. 
 
ROS: As per HPI.
 
Past Medical History:
- ESRD ___ ___ s/p DDRT (___)
- Excision of Left UE AVF in ___
- H/o of nephrolithiasis  
- Afib on Eliquis  
- H/o Hematuria attributed to cyst rupture  
- Hypertension
- Anemia  
- Uterine prolapse  
- H/O Latent Coccidiomycosis s/p Fluconazole PPX

Brief Hospital Course:
Ms. ___ is a ___ woman with ESRD secondary to ___ 
s/p DDRT on ___ here with multi-drug resistant Klebsiella 
UTI admitted for treatment with IV Meropenem. The patient was 
seen in primary care clinic on ___ with burning with urination 
and increased frequency. A urine analysis was positive for 
nitrites and large amount of leukocyte esterase. The patient 
took two days of ciprofloxacin with improvement in her dysuria. 
The urine culture grew > 100,000 Klebsiella sensitive only to 
Meropenem so the patient admitted for IV antibiotics. 
 
# Urinary Tract Infection: Due to multi-drug resistant 
Klebsiella. The patient was seen in primary care clinic on ___ 
with burning with urination and increased frequency. A urine 
analysis was positive for nitrites and large amount of leukocyte 
esterase. The patient took two days of ciprofloxacin with 
improvement in her dysuria. The urine culture grew > 100,000 
Klebsiella sensitive only to Meropenem so the patient admitted 
for IV antibiotics (Day 1 ___. Sensitivities were sent for 
ertapenem and fosfomycin, to determine if patient could have a 
more convenient regimen at discharge. The klebsiella was 
sensitive to fosfomycin, and transplant ID was consulted for 
approval of the medication and dosing instructions. She was 
discharged on fosfomycin 3 g q3days to complete at total 14 day 
course of treatment.
 
# ESRD: s/p DDRT ___. Baseline Creat 0.8-0.9. Patient has a 
history of metabolic acidosis on sodium bicarbonate. Luminex 
from ___ without any HLA antibodies. CDC increased risk 
donor, BBID labs ___ show HIV neg, HCV Ab neg, HepBAg neg, 
HepBsAB positive, HepBcAb positive. BK Virus PCR urine < 500 in 
___. Left upper extremity AV fistula resected ___. 
Continued Tacrolimus 2 mg BID with goal trough ___. Continued 
MMF 1g BID. Continue Bactrim prophylaxis. Increased Lamivudine 
prophylaxis from 50 mg daily to 100 mg daily based on renal 
function.

# Hypertension: On hydralazine 50 mg BID at home. Held morning 
hydralazine during this admission given SBPs in 100s, and then 
discontinued hydralazine for discharge as was persistently in 
the 100s with 25 mg bid. Continued metoprolol succinate 25 mg 
daily. Continued amlodipine 5 mg daily.

# Atrial fibrillation: Continued metoprolol succinate 25 mg 
daily. Continued apixaban 5 mg BID.

Transitional Issues:
#Given adequate creatinine clearance, increased Lamivudine from 
50 mg to 100 mg.
#F/u blood pressures, hydralazine stopped because of sbps in low 
100s.
#Fosfomycin stop date: ___
#Full code
#Contact: ___ (daughter): HCP ___

Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
==============
PRIMARY:
==============
- Urinary Tract Infection, MDR Klebsiella 

==============
SECONDARY:
==============
- End-Stage Renal Disease s/p Deceased Donor Renal Transplant
- Hypertension
- Atrial fibrillaiton

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. ___,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your recent 
admission to ___. You came to 
us because you were having burning with urination. We found that 
you had a urinary tract infection with a bacteria that was 
resistant to many antibiotics. We gave you antibiotics by IV to 
treat your infection, and you were discharged with medications 
to take by mouth. The schedule of when to take this medication 
is below.

Please remember to take all of your medications as prescribed. 
If you start to develop pain or burning with urination again, or 
if you develop fevers, back pain, or general worsening of well 
being, please seek medical attention.

We wish you the best of health.

Sincerely,
Your ___ Care Team

Fosfomycin (antibiotic) dates:
Take on ___.
 
Followup Instructions:
___

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
